content.preview: As part of our exciting new Art in the Park initiative, the Conservancy welcomed its third
content.full_text:
As part of our exciting new Art in the Park initiative, the Conservancy welcomed its third

sculpture, “Clunie Spiral”, to Waveny Park on Thursday, November 7th. The new sculpture has been placed near the top of the sledding hill leading to Anderson Pond, along the edge where the Lapham’s old swimming pool was installed. A permanent base still needs to be installed and final positioning tweaked but delivery and unloading went smoothly thanks to our New Canaan town partners at the Parks and Recreation and Highway Departments.  “Clunie Spiral” is generously donated by Kathy Megrue-Smith. A formal unveiling and dedication is planned for the future.

“Clunie Spiral” is the third in a series of

planned for the Park. Sculpted by the Scottish artist, Nigel Ross, the first two sculptures arrived at the Park in early 2024 as part of a long-term plan for select organic outdoor sculptures. “Crossways” sits on the knoll at the north end of Jeniam Meadow and “Arbor” borders the lawn and Upper Meadow at the back of the house. While Ross has a couple of his sculptures in the United States, the Park’s plan for a

consisting of a total of five of Ross’s sculptures is unique.  As functional art, they

are designed to be sat and climbed on and we encourage you to bring your children to experience them. All three sculptures are approximately 11 to 12 feet long and weigh half to three quarters of a ton.

We are grateful for the efforts of our former board member and colleague, Charles Crookenden, who worked tirelessly to bring the

program to Waveny. A fourth sculpture is already on order as a tribute to him.

Woodlands restoration is underway!

Your financial contribution to the Waveny Park Conservancy is essential in helping to fund one of New Canaan’s most beloved parks.

content.preview: The woodlands restoration project is underway at Waveny Park!  Work began in early January and is expected to continue over the next several years.  The project will remove invasives and undergrowth in an effort to restore native plant species that are typically present in a healthy Connecticut woodland. These native plants and shrubs provide important food, nesting grounds and cover for native birds and animals. The Conservancy is funding this work with a major grant form the Jeniam Foundation
content.full_text:
The woodlands restoration project is underway at Waveny Park!  Work began in early January and is expected to continue over the next several years.  The project will remove invasives and undergrowth in an effort to restore native plant species that are typically present in a healthy Connecticut woodland. These native plants and shrubs provide important food, nesting grounds and cover for native birds and animals. The Conservancy is funding this work with a major grant form the Jeniam Foundation

Woodlands restoration is underway!

content.preview: Woodlands restoration at Waveny Park is underway. The project has been in the planning for the past 18 months and is expected to continue through the next several years. Invasive and undesirable plants and shrubs will be removed from the understory to encourage the growth of native species that are typically present in a healthy Connecticut woodland. The Conservancy is funding this work with a major grant from the Jeniam Foundation.
content.full_text:
Woodlands restoration at Waveny Park is underway. The project has been in the planning for the past 18 months and is expected to continue through the next several years. Invasive and undesirable plants and shrubs will be removed from the understory to encourage the growth of native species that are typically present in a healthy Connecticut woodland. The Conservancy is funding this work with a major grant from the Jeniam Foundation.

Your financial contribution to the Waveny Park Conservancy is essential in helping to fund one of New Canaan’s most beloved parks.

Our town.title: Filling in the Blanks – Unite To Fight – 5K

content.preview: On Sunday, August 21st 2022, Filling in the Blanks will host the fourth annual Unite to Fight 5K. The race will once again take place at New Canaan High School and will be run through the idyllic Waveny Park in New Canaan. This race seeks to build community through raising funds to provide weekend meals for children facing food insecurity in local neighborhoods.
content.full_text:
On Sunday, August 21st 2022, Filling in the Blanks will host the fourth annual Unite to Fight 5K. The race will once again take place at New Canaan High School and will be run through the idyllic Waveny Park in New Canaan. This race seeks to build community through raising funds to provide weekend meals for children facing food insecurity in local neighborhoods.

Raising $35,338 with 249 participants, the race exceeded all expectations in 2021 and helped expand our program to assist 116 more children with a year’s worth of weekend meals! This year you have the unique opportunity to get in early as a staple sponsor of this event, which will benefit your brand, and help us continue to grow that success to do even more!

In Fairfield County, more than 33,000 children are not sure where their next meal will come from. Most will get breakfast and lunch from school every weekday, but many will go from Friday lunch until Monday at breakfast without a decent meal. Filling in the Blanks is an organization that fills in those weekend gaps by providing each child in its program with a backpack filled with healthy food for the weekend. When the obstacle of food insecurity is removed, children experience increased academic achievement in school and greater opportunities for success in their lives.

Founded in 2013 by two Fairfield County residents, Tina Kramer and Shawnee Knight, Filling in the Blanks is a 501c3 non-profit organization that has grown from serving 50 kids to serving more than 4,000 kids in Fairfield and Westchester counties.

The Unite to Fight 5K event was inspired through the memory of Kristen Reynolds Ruth, a local kindergarten teacher, mother and friend, who passed in 2011 after a 7-year battle with cancer and was deeply passionate about working with and helping children. The event was created and is directed by her daughter, an NCHS alumni, Britt Gardella.

WITH YOUR EVENT REGISTRATION, YOU WILL RECEIVE THE FOLLOWING:

Unite to Fight 5K T-shirt, available for local pick up the week of the race.*

Gift certificates for top three men and women race finishers

Unite to Fight 5K medals for age group winners

*Participants registering after August 10th 2022 may not receive a shirt.

REGISTER

Town Hall

77 Main Street

New Canaan, CT 06840

(203) 594-3000

(203) 594-3123

New Canaan YMCA.title: New Programs & Activities Launching This Fall

content.preview: Facility Update: Sunday, 2/16/25 | The Y is currently closed due to an issue with our fire alarm system.
content.full_text:
The Y will introduce new programs for kids, teens, and adults providing opportunities for all ages to grow, learn something new, and join in on the fun at the Y this fall.

Registration for fall programs is currently available online and at the Y. Fall programs range in session length and begin Wednesday, August 30. Several programs are open to both members and non-members of the New Canaan YMCA, with members receiving a program discount as a benefit of their membership. Financial assistance for membership and program fees is also available thanks to donations to the Y.

In addition to the popular returning programs such as swim lessons, Bouncing Bears gymnastics, and youth sports and wellness programs, the Y is excited to launch new youth recreation and Red Cross certification programs.

New recreation programs for preschoolers include Lunch Bunch and the Dino Den, as well as a Let’s Build: Legos class for children in kindergarten through third grade. The Y’s weekly lunch bunch group will feature a variety of games and activities including STEM, music and movement, puppet making, and more. Dino Den is an enriching program that will teach children all about dinosaurs including a weekly dino of the day in addition to fun activities and educational videos. The Y’s Lego-building class is designed for kids to explore creative Lego themes and will provide guided group builds and individual builds that will keep kids engaged while learning teamwork and having fun.

The Y’s recreation department will also debut several middle school programs this fall including percussion, music, and crafting classes where participants can hone skills, learn something new, and make friends. The Y’s percussion program will introduce middle schoolers to the unique beats and rhythms of drumming using a diverse array of percussion instruments. Aspiring middle school musicians may also partake in the Y’s music class which will introduce folk music, acapella, body percussion, guitar, and banjo. The Y’s master crafters class inspires creativity through creating projects including nature mobiles, suncatchers, and 3D name plates, in addition to learning the concepts of perspective, color theory, and negative space.

The Y will also be introducing additional safety certification courses this fall. In addition to the Junior Lifeguarding Course available to ages 11-14 and the Red Cross Babysitting course available to ages 11-15, new courses will be offered to teens and adults in the community. These courses include Red Cross First Aid, CPR, & AED Training for ages 12-17, and Red Cross Safety Training for Swim Coaches, Red Cross Basic Life Support Training for Healthcare & Public Safety, and Red Cross First Aid, CPR, AED, & Opioid Overdose Training for the Professional Rescuer for ages 16 and older. The Y will also offer a First Aid, CPR, & AED Training course for ages 18 and older. Each course is a one-day program and is open to New Canaan YMCA members and the community.

Kids and teens looking to find their team or try something new this fall can participate in tryouts for the Y’s Whirlwind Diving and Caimans Swim teams’ upcoming fall seasons. The Whirlwind Diving team is currently hosting try-outs through Friday, August 25 from 3:00-6:00 PM at the Y. Those interested in scheduling a try-out for the Whirlwind Diving team can contact Adam Vance, Associate Competitive Diving Director, at 203-920-1658 or

. The Caimans Swim team is hosting try-outs on Wednesday, August 30, and Thursday, August 31 from 5:00-6:30 PM at the Y. Those interested in scheduling a tryout for the Caimans Swim team can contact Liz Blau, Associate Competitive Swimming Director, at 203-920-1645 or

.

The New Canaan YMCA is also excited to announce a new program in its chronic disease support offerings. In addition to the LIVESTRONG at the YMCA cancer survivor program, Diabetes Prevention Program (DPP), and as an addition to its current programming for those with Parkinson’s Disease, the Y will be introducing Pedaling for Parkinson’s this fall. Riding an indoor stationary bicycle has been shown to reduce Parkinson’s motor symptoms by as much as 35%, and it’s something that almost anyone with Parkinson’s disease can do. The Y’s Pedaling for Parkinson’s program is designed to offer an hour ride on an indoor stationary bike starting with a 10-minute warm-up, 40 minutes with resistance, and a 10-minute cool-down. Those interested in learning more about the program can contact Eva Saint, New Canaan YMCA Wellness Director, to learn more at 203-920-1623 or

.

A complete listing of fall programming is available online at www.newcanaanymca.org. For additional information regarding fall programs or registration, call 203-966-4528. For additional information about membership at the Y and to schedule a tour, contact Mary Coleman, Membership Director, at 203-920-1630. Thanks to donations made to the New Canaan YMCA, financial assistance is available for both membership and program fees. To learn more about financial assistance at the Y, contact Diana Riolo, Assistant Director of Development & Community Impact, at 203-920-1653 or

.

New Canaan YMCA.title: YMCA and Parks & Recreation Partner to Teach Nearly 200 Children to Swim This Summer

content.preview: Facility Update: Sunday, 2/16/25 | The Y is currently closed due to an issue with our fire alarm system.
content.full_text:
The New Canaan YMCA and New Canaan Parks and Recreation Department are thrilled to share the culmination of a successful first-year partnership providing nearly 200 kids in our community with swim lessons at the Steve Benko Pool in Waveny Park.

Five mornings per week at the Steve Benko Pool, New Canaan YMCA swim instructors taught children ages six months through twelve years old and focused on safety, confidence, and strength in the water in a fun and nurturing environment.

While children learned the important skill of swimming, their parents and caregivers learned about safety in and out of the water. According to the CDC, drowning is the leading cause of death for children ages one to four and the second leading cause of death for children ages five to fourteen. The Y’s swim lesson program incorporated a weekly water safety lesson for parents and caregivers during swim lessons. Water Safety Wednesdays, led by Matt Busse, New Canaan YMCA Director of Aquatic Operations & Safety, taught parents and caregivers pool and beach safety, aquatic emergency preparedness, and hands-only CPR lessons that provide life-saving skills far beyond the summer.

“We are very proud to have partnered with the Parks and Recreation Department on this initiative. In addition to helping 200 kids become safer and stronger in the water, our summer swim lessons at the Steve Benko pool were an excellent example of how a community nonprofit and the Town can join in partnership to further our common goal of serving our community members. The Y is always exploring ways to expand our services and we look forward to future partnerships,” shared Margaret Riley, New Canaan YMCA Executive Director.

Zack Philippas, Assistant Director of New Canaan Parks and Recreation, shared, “Our goal here at New Canaan Recreation is to provide recreational, educational, and social programs for all New Canaan Residents. Partnering with a reputable organization such as the YMCA of New Canaan has given us the opportunity to offer quality swim lessons while maximizing the usage of Steve Benko Pool. We are already looking forward to next season!”

To learn more about the Y’s swim lessons program, visit

. To learn more about the New Canaan Recreation Department, visit

.

New Canaan YMCA.title: Melisa’s Monthly Message: Don’t Let Fall Get You Down

content.preview: Facility Update: Sunday, 2/16/25 | The Y is currently closed due to an issue with our fire alarm system.
content.full_text:
Falls are the leading cause of fatal and nonfatal injuries for older Americans and one single fall doubles your risk of falling again.  The complications from a fall can be devastating, and even in the best-case scenario can affect our independence and ability to participate in essential as well as enjoyable activities.

It’s true that as we age our chances of experiencing a fall increase, but falls are caused by a number of risk factors that can affect a person of any age.  The time to recognize risk and reduce risk factors is long before our age alone increases our likelihood of falling.

Let’s reduce and control our risk factors today!

Look for more information about our Fall Prevention Lecture and demonstration presented by Stamford Health and HSS on October 27

here at the Y.   Dr. Bret Sohn will also be here at the Y in October to talk about arthritis (October 10

) as well as Dr. Edward Schuster (October 24

) with his advice on longevity and good health.  I’m available at various times each week to check blood pressure, so stop by (or email me for availability at a specific time

).  And the opportunities to strengthen core and improve balance are endless here at the Y, so take advantage of as many as you can.

Stay upright, and keep moving!

Melisa,

Y Wellness Nurse Coordinator

New Canaan YMCA.title: New Canaan YMCA Awards $200,000 in Financial Assistance Thanks to Community Support

content.preview: Facility Update: Sunday, 2/16/25 | The Y is currently closed due to an issue with our fire alarm system.
content.full_text:
The New Canaan YMCA proudly awarded nearly $200,000 in financial assistance this past year thanks to the generous support of donations, continuing the organization’s commitment to providing every individual the opportunity to benefit from the Y regardless of financial circumstances.

Financial assistance assures that hundreds of families and individuals facing financial hardship have opportunities for YMCA experiences. Donations make it possible for the Y to provide financial support for memberships and program fees, benefiting families and individuals of all ages from kids to seniors.

“Receiving financial assistance to join the New Canaan YMCA has been a game-changer. The facility’s range of activities and welcoming environment have allowed me to decompress from work and school. Regular workouts and engaging classes became a source of stress relief, boosting my mood and energy levels. The sense of community was invaluable, reducing feelings of isolation. I have discovered new hobbies, improved my physical health, and found a supportive space to enhance my overall well-being. Being able to continue my membership aligns with my personal growth and happiness,” shared a recent financial assistance recipient.

Financial support from the New Canaan Y’s donors makes a meaningful difference in the lives of many, providing adults with the opportunity to maintain both physical and mental health, providing seniors with the opportunity to remain physically active and socially connected, providing safe and reliable childcare to working families, and providing children with the opportunity to build confidence and character, make lasting friendships, develop healthy habits, and have fun through programs such as swim lessons, summer camp, sports, social activities, competitive teams, special needs programs, and leadership opportunities.

“The Y’s financial assistance program helps to further the Y’s mission of enriching all people in spirit, mind, and body,” said New Canaan YMCA’s Executive Director, Margaret Riley. “We are very grateful to our donors who generously fund this initiative, which enables our Y to serve as a true source of community—fully inclusive, supportive, and attainable to all.”

Anyone interested in learning more about financial assistance support for membership or programs at the New Canaan YMCA is encouraged to contact the Financial Assistance office at 203-920-1653 or

. Financial assistance applications can be obtained at the Y’s Front Desk or online at www.newcanaanymca.org.

Visit www.newcanaanymca.org/donate to make a donation to the New Canaan YMCA, which supports the financial assistance program as well as other life-changing programs supporting individuals with special needs, cancer survivors, seniors, teens, and others within our community.

New Canaan YMCA.title: Melisa’s Monthly Message: Mammograms… and More

content.preview: Facility Update: Sunday, 2/16/25 | The Y is currently closed due to an issue with our fire alarm system.
content.full_text:
In addition to rich autumn color tones, pink has become the color of October. According to the CDC, cancer is the second leading cause of death in American women. We recognize the importance of screening for breast cancer, which has more favorable outcomes if detected and treated early.

• Understand your risk factors

• Perform monthly breast self-exams

• Get your mammogram!

The CDC also reports the leading cause of death in women is heart disease.  Did you know that women are much more likely to experience less common symptoms of a heart attack? Women may manifest symptoms as indigestion, shortness of breath, and back pain, sometimes even in the absence of obvious chest discomfort.

Stay well, and stay informed!

Melisa,

Y Wellness Nurse Coordinator

Stamford Health’s breast program coordinator will be stationed here at the Y to help answer any questions you may have about mammography, and facilitate scheduling of your mammogram at one of Stamford Health’s award-winning multimodality breast imaging centers.

content.preview: NCCF hosted its 2025 Annual Meeting on January 29, 2025 at the Waveny House.  With approximately 135 friends of the Foundation in attendance, the event began with a Meet and Greet Cocktail Reception followed by the Annual Meeting.  Jeff Williams, NCCF Board Chair, Jim Clayton, NCCF Treasurer, and Lauren Patterson, NCCF President and CEO, presented a “State of the Foundation” update.  This was followed by remarks from our partners, New Canaan Cares’ Colleen Prostor, Positive Directions’ Margaret Watts, and Silver Hill Hospital’s Dr. Andrew Gerber on new initiatives and grant investments related to our ongoing efforts to improve Behavioral Health in our town.
content.full_text:
NCCF hosted its 2025 Annual Meeting on January 29, 2025 at the Waveny House.  With approximately 135 friends of the Foundation in attendance, the event began with a Meet and Greet Cocktail Reception followed by the Annual Meeting. New Canaan Community Foundation.title: NCCF Young Philanthropist Program Awards $24,500 to 6 Nonprofit Organizations

content.full_text: NCCF’s Young Philanthropists Program awarded $24,500 in grants to six nonprofit organizations. Throughout the past school year, this group of over 20 high school students explored important local needs and philanthropy’s role in addressing those issues. They visited nonprofit organizations to see them in action, managed their own fundraising campaigns, and reviewed grant requests.  Through this program, NCCF is doing its part to create the next generation of philanthropists.

New Canaan Community Foundation.title: NCCF Awards $863,000 in Grants to 91 Nonprofits

content.preview: NCCF allocated $863,000 in grants to benefit 91 nonprofit organizations in New Canaan and neighboring communities. The Foundation celebrated the grant recipients at its awards ceremony on Wednesday, June 5, 2024, at Grace Farms in New Canaan, CT.
content.full_text:
NCCF allocated $863,000 in grants to benefit 91 nonprofit organizations in New Canaan and neighboring communities. The Foundation celebrated the grant recipients at its awards ceremony on Wednesday, June 5, 2024, at Grace Farms in New Canaan, CT.

Grants awarded by category:

$223,000 to 19 organizations that provide community members with cultural, recreational and educational resources.

$160,500 to 18 organizations that provide community members with information and access to services they need to stay healthy. The category includes, $111,000 to ten organizations whose work focuses on Behavioral Health, an area NCCF has prioritized for the past six years.

$227,000 to 21 organizations that ensure community members are able to meet their basic needs.

$128,600 to 13 organizations that ensure older adults with disabilities achieve and maintain a high quality of life.

$116,750 to 18 organizations that ensure youth have academic, social, and financial support they need to succeed. Two additional organizations were supported solely by Newcomers co-investments.

For a complete list of all grantees and the award amounts:

New Canaan Community Foundation.title: NCCF Welcomes New Board Members and Development Director

content.preview: New Canaan, CT, June 26, 2024
content.full_text:
– The New Canaan Community Foundation (NCCF) proudly welcomes four new members to its Board of Directors. The NCCF board is led by more than 20 volunteers and civic leaders, who seek to understand and represent a wide variety of issues impacting the local community.

●

is the Director of Major Gifts and Alumni Affairs at New Canaan Country School, a New Canaan native, and an active member of our local community. Prior to joining the team at NCCS, Holly held various roles in fundraising and special events at Americares, a global health organization founded here in New Canaan and headquartered in Stamford.  Holly has volunteered in many capacities at NCCF, including Annual Appeal Co-Chair, Luncheon Committee, and Grant Reviewer, among others. She was also the recipient of the NCCF Impact Award during NCCF’s Volunteer Recognition Awards in 2023.

●

has been the Chief Medical Officer for the Stamford Health Medical Group since 2014, a practicing Internist specializing in Nephrology and an attending physician at Stamford Hospital.  He was part of a collaborative project with Liberation Programs which brought behavioral health services to Stamford Health outpatient practices. Bill has volunteered with the NCCF's Behavioral Health Committee since 2023.

●

is a Vice President and Banker in the Greenwich, CT, office of J.P. Morgan Private Bank. She is passionate about working alongside individuals and families to transform their life goals into a deeply impactful legacy.  She is a Board Emeritus Member and former Board Chair and CEO for Hope for Haiti, an organization founded by her grandmother.  She serves as a National Board Member for Reach Out and Read, a pediatric literacy model providing a foundation for success through relational health and education. Tiffany also serves on NCCF’s Behavioral Health Committee and has previously served as a Co-Chair for NCCF’s Annual Luncheon.

●

is the Co-owner of Walter Stewart’s Market with his brother Doug. Together, they own and operate Walter Stewart’s Market, founded in 1907 by their great-grandfather, along with the adjacent Stewart’s Wine and Spirits, founded by their uncle in 1974. As a fourth-generation New Canaanite he embodies a generational commitment to New Canaan through family business and community service. Alex has served on the boards of the Chamber of Commerce and the New Canaan Cemetery Association and has been on the NCCF Volunteer Recognition Committee since 2017.

"We are delighted to welcome Holly, Bill, Tiffany, and Alex to our board," said Jeff Williams, Chair of the NCCF Board of Directors. "Each of their diverse backgrounds and deep ties to New Canaan will bring a wealth of knowledge to our board within their respective areas and allow us to continue to serve our community’s needs."

●

, Chair of the Board

●

, Vice Chair

●

, Vice Chair

●

, Governance

●

, Treasurer

Jayne Benton, Eileen Boyd, Monica Capela Chimera, Dan Harris, Suzanne Harrison, Jim Huetter, Karen Mactas, Dan Rashin, Michael Reed, Michelle Riley, Sara Schubert, John Sheffield, Marley Thackray, Ross Weiner, and Kristina Woods.

In addition to the new board, NCCF is proud to announce it has also hired a new Development Director,

.  Carrie has served as a volunteer for the Foundation and other local nonprofit organizations since moving to New Canaan in 2013.

"We are thrilled to have Carrie join us as Development Director," said Lauren Patterson, President & CEO of the New Canaan Community Foundation. "Her past corporate experience, combined with her passion for our mission, will be instrumental in advancing our development efforts."  Carrie joins the team following the move out of state of the current Development Director, Lauren Erickson, who will remain engaged with NCCF on key activities.

Carrie Kurtz joins NCCF’s full-time staff:

●

, President & CEO

●

, Program Officer

●

, Development & Communications Associate

●

, Finance and Operations Manager

content.preview: The Gridiron Club of New Canaan recently presented the New Canaan Community Foundation (NCCF) with a generous donation of $8,000, proceeds from Gridiron’s annual show. content.preview: Waveny Park in New Canaan, Connecticut was originally a grand summer estate owned by Thomas Wells Hall from 1894 to 1904. The Carriage Barn and Powerhouse were built during this period. In 1904, Lewis Henry Lapham, a co-founder of the Texaco Oil Company, bought the property as a summer estate from Hall, and expanded it from 280 acres to 450 acres.
content.full_text:
Waveny Park in New Canaan, Connecticut was originally a grand summer estate owned by Thomas Wells Hall from 1894 to 1904. The Carriage Barn and Powerhouse were built during this period. In 1904, Lewis Henry Lapham, a co-founder of the Texaco Oil Company, bought the property as a summer estate from Hall, and expanded it from 280 acres to 450 acres.

Lapham tore down Hall's house and had a new one built in 1912 by the renowned architect William B. Tubby of Greenwich. The new house was named Waveny House after Waveny River in England where Lapham ancestors had once lived. The landscape design for the property was by the Olmsted Brothers Firm, sons of Frederick Law Olmsted, Jr., who designed Central Park. The house sits majestically overlooking hundreds of acres of immaculate gardens and grounds.

In August of 1967, the Town of New Canaan purchased Waveny Park from Mrs. Ruth Lapham Lloyd, the daughter of Lewis Lapham Lloyd. The House is the centerpiece of an outstanding community recreation area enjoyed by the residents of the Town. It is open to the public and may be rented for a variety of functions through the New Canaan Recreation Department, which is located on the second floor of the House. The first floor of Waveny House consists of the grand hall, the library, sitting room, dining/breakfast room, billiard room, a patio which overlooks the beautiful grounds, and a complete commercial kitchen. On the second floor are four gracious rooms which are used for conferences and meetings.

Lewis Henry Lapham

Ruth Lapham Lloyd

The park is bordered by Farm Road to the North, the Merritt Parkway to the South, South Avenue to the East and Lapham Road to the West. Over the years, numerous additional structures have been built or re-purposed on parts of the property. The park contains approximately 3.5 miles of jogging/walking trails, soccer, baseball and softball fields, picnic areas, Waveny Park Swimming Facility, artificial turf Water Tower Field and lots of open space. Waveny Park also contains the PowerHouse Performing Arts Center, The Carriage Barn Art Center, Spencer's Run Dog Park, Lapham Community Center and The Waveny Lodge and Platform Tennis Courts.

Sign up with your email address to receive news and updates.

We respect your privacy.

New Canaan High School.title: Join Us for the Annual NC Color Drop – March 22 at Waveny Park!

content.preview: New Canaan Public Schools
content.full_text:
Mark your calendars for one of New Canaan’s most exciting annual traditions—the NC Color Drop! On Saturday, March 22, at 10:00 AM, a helicopter will soar over Waveny Park, releasing 2,000 numbered golf balls onto a target below. The participants whose golf balls land closest to the target will win one of 26 incredible prizes from local businesses, with the grand prize being a 2025 Chevy Colorado! Best of all, 100% of the proceeds support need-based college scholarships for NCHS graduates. Spectators are welcome to watch the drop and cheer on the winners.

for more details and to purchase your golf balls!

content.preview: New Canaan Public Schools
content.full_text:
Dear Senior and Parent or Guardian:

Graduation preparations and end-of-year events are underway. Many particulars are involved, so please read carefully and ensure you are approaching graduation with a clear understanding of your obligations and how these can be most easily met. Here are the specifics:

The ceremony is scheduled for Wednesday, June 12th, beginning promptly at 10:30 AM. Parents, guardians, and guests may enter the stadium at 9:30 AM.

If the weather is an issue, the ceremony could be delayed to later that day or postponed to the next day at 10:30 AM.

The Class of 2024 will march onto the field and sit facing the scoreboard. Therefore, home and visitor stands will be available for families. As the graduates process into the stadium, they will be seated alphabetically on either side of the field (approximately A - L on the “visitor” side and  M - Z on the “home’ side). Please note that students will know their precise location after graduation rehearsal on Tuesday, June 11th.

are not required for the graduation ceremony, and there is no limit on the number of guests for each graduate.

If anyone has mobility issues, please contact Ari Rothman at

. The parking lot between the gymnasium and Dunning Stadium will be blocked off for handicapped parking, with 30 spaces.

: A professional photographer, Island Photography, hired by the class, will take a picture as each graduate receives their diploma. An email link to a photo proof will be sent within a week after graduation. You can select from various packages, but there is no obligation to purchase anything.

A $60.00 fee covers the cost of senior events and a cap and gown. This fee can be paid online through

. If paying this fee is a hardship, please contact your grade-level administrator, Larry Sullivan, as soon as possible at

Caps and gowns have been ordered for all seniors and are required at graduation. Beginning June 3rd, students who have paid for and resolved all financial obligations may pick up their cap and gown in the attendance office from 8:00 am - 3:00 pm, Monday through Friday.

Financial obligations are found in PowerSchool - parking violations, non-returned textbooks, library materials, or athletics.

Obligations can be paid online through

.

Please double-check that your

has no outstanding balances.

Please see Mrs. Pescatello in the main office for any questions about obligations.

Final transcripts will only be released to colleges if fully completed, and you will not be able to pick up your cap and gown.

The

as specified in emails sent to students.

Seniors can access the survey in the “About Me” section in Naviance. Once there, click on “ Surveys from your school” and then scroll down and click on the left “Surveys not started.” Please do not leave any college decisions 'unknown' UNLESS it was a waitlist.  See Mrs. Granite if you never followed through on some applications. Then, input where to send your final transcript and check the box to which school you will be attending. (This will enable Mrs. Granite to send your final transcript to the college you will attend.) We understand that some of you are waiting to hear from schools that you have been waitlisted. You can make changes once you have heard from them, but please let us know where you have deposited and are currently planning to attend and what the changes were. Answer every question. If you have any questions, please email

.

All seniors who applied to the NCAA Clearinghouse and still want to be NCAA certified as eligible to play collegiate sports

notify Mrs. Granite, the Registrar, or your final transcript

be sent to the Clearinghouse.

– Students who have not satisfied all academic requirements for graduation will not participate in the graduation ceremony.

Lastly, below is a calendar listing the END OF YEAR EVENTS! Please remember that all school rules, particularly the use of any prohibited and/or illegal substance, are still in effect. Any violation will jeopardize participation in the commencement or other senior activities. The school reserves the right to remove any student from the Graduation Ceremony. Good judgment and safe conduct will lead to a happy and fulfilling end-of-year and graduation week for all.

New Canaan High School.title: NCHS Cinderella Shines Onstage with Student Music Director, Henry Tate

content.preview: New Canaan Public Schools
content.full_text:
Written by Kole Bavoso, NCPS Communications Intern

This past weekend, the New Canaan High School’s Theatre Department performed their Spring production—Rodgers and Hammerstein’s Cinderella. The musical follows the story of Ella [Annabelle Murphy] who is forced into being subservient to her villainous stepmother, Madame [Kole Bavoso]. Ella wishes she could go out and explore the world. Revolutionary Jean-Michel [Thomas Pisant] tries to open the peoples’ eyes to injustice in their kingdom while Lord Pinkleton [Hank Durfee] announces Prince Topher’s [Bennett Gropper] ball to find a queen. Aided by her fairy godmother, Marie [Hannah Reid], Ella transforms out of her rags and into a beautiful gown and meets the Prince at the ball. The two share a kiss. Madame tries to persuade Lord Protector Sebastian [Nick Mohamad] into having one of her daughters, the beautiful Gabrielle [Catherine Haddad], meet the Prince and become Queen. Madame’s other daughter, Charlotte [Sophie Jones], laments the fact that her sister is always the one guys are drawn to.

The show featured many Seniors performing in their final production at New Canaan High School, one of which being Kole Bavoso. Kole played the part of Madame and had such an incredible time working on the show. Cinderella was the first show where Kole played the antagonist, offering a very different experience to their repertoire. Kole admits, “It was difficult to play someone as mean and terrifying as Madame. But with the help of our director, every day I felt more confident in my role.” Kole even said that, as they got closer to the show, they began to take more risks with their character, which ultimately paid off comedically. “I remember adding in small moments that gave Madame more character, like adding in an evil laugh after a line or throwing my cloak at Ella.” These small details, Kole notes, made this role an unforgettable experience.

This production was one of the biggest the New Canaan High School auditorium saw this year. “It was really satisfying to look out into the audience from the stage and see hundreds of people smiling back at you,” remarks Kole. “The energy of an audience is a big part of the excitement of performing, so—when there is a big audience—us actors feel so much enthusiasm on stage.”

Kole admits that it was difficult to replicate the overwhelmingly positive reception the underclassmen Fall musical Mean Girls received. But Cinderella attracted an audience of all different ages, from little kids wearing their Cinderella gowns all the way to parents and grandparents watching their young thespian on stage. The show was such an enjoyable and entertaining experience that drew in people from not only New Canaan, but all over the Fairfield County area.

The production was directed by Matt Blank, choreographed by Emily Frangipane, and music directed by Henry Tate—a Junior at New Canaan High School. Henry was ecstatic to music direct Cinderella, being the first student to ever do so. Henry usually can be seen on stage as an actor, most recently starring as Robert Martin in The Drowsy Chaperone at New Canaan High School. Adding to a successful young acting career, Henry Tate decided he wanted to see what else theater has to offer him. While serving as assistant music director, he “really enjoyed the experience of being more involved.”

As someone who has always been involved with music, Henry said, “I’ve really enjoyed combining my longtime love for playing piano with theatre. The two coming together has been really gratifying.” As music director, he had many responsibilities—teaching the cast their lyrics, and melodies, cleaning long sections of singing, and playing the piano as accompaniment during rehearsals. Henry spent many hours every week helping the cast on and off stage and has tackled this huge feat very thoroughly. “There is so much that goes into being the music director that I never even imagined,” Henry shares, “putting all the intricate details of this show together has felt like a huge accomplishment.”

The cast is very thankful for Henry and all that he did to prepare them for the incredible show they put on. With the seniors off to college next year, the Juniors now step up as the next leaders in the department. Henry will certainly be ready for any responsibilities thrown his way this coming year, whether he is acting on the stage or music directing again.

Photo Contributions by Henry Tate

images.alt_text: nchs cinderella shines on stage, with student music director, henry tate

New Canaan High School.title: NCHS Girls Lacrosse Team Wins 2024 CIAC LL Title

content.preview: New Canaan Public Schools
content.full_text:
Repost from

, 'They've Carried on Our Culture': New Canaan Girls Lacross Beat Darien for CIAC LL Title." by Terry Dinan | June 9, 2024

It was a lot of déjà vu all over again at Sacred Heart University’s Campus Field on Saturday afternoon.

For the third consecutive year it was New Canaan-Darien in the CIAC Girls Lacrosse Championship. The same matchup as it has been for the previous four FCIAC Championship Games. And just like the conference final played 16 days ago, it was the Rams who came away with a five-goal win as New Canaan downed the top-seeded Blue Wave 10-5 to take the Class LL crown.

“I am just so happy for this team,” New Canaan head coach Kristin Woods said. “They worked their butts off all season. I kept telling them practice is going to be harder than game, and it paid off.”

Helped by a standout performance from junior goalie Ceci Patterson (8 saves), a stout defensive performance and long offensive possessions that usually ended with scores, the No. 2-seeded Rams reeled off six consecutive goals to turn a 3-2 nail-biter at the end of the first period into a comfortable 9-2 lead heading into the game’s final minutes. Darien’s Anna Van Kennel scored three goals in the last 2:30 of the contest to keep the Blue Wave’s hopes alive – but it was too little, too late.

“Maintaining possession on the draws was super important,” senior co-captain Devon Russell said. “We had Kat Norton and Lexie Tully try it and we were successful switching that up against (Darien’s) Sadie Stafford who was doing great on the draw.”

“I think defensively we stopped the break – they scored two quick ones off breaks,” Woods told

. “They just played together and that’s the best part about this team. There is no one kid that is going to do it all. Every single person was a weapon out there.”

As they have all season, the Rams showed remarkable patience on the offensive end—not forcing bad shots and relying on ball control, movement and forcing Darien to make mistakes, resulting in numerous eight-meter free position opportunities. New Canaan received goals from six different players – Emma Row, Maddie Tully, Lexie Tully, Devon Russell, Sydney Patten and Addie Crowley – with Row, both Tully sisters and Russell leading the way with two scores apiece.

The win was New Canaan’s eighth state championship (2010, 2012, 2013, 2015, 2016, 2018, 2022, 2024) and marks the second time in program history that the Rams captured both the FCIAC and CIAC titles (2022 being the other). The victory erased not only the bad memories of last year’s state final (won by Darien 14-13) but also a 5-5 tie with the Wave back on April 25

.

“We knew that tie earlier in the season definitely wasn’t our best game,” Russell said, “The fact that we tied them and knew we had a lot to work on was really encouraging. We implemented that in that FCIAC game and to come back here and play them again we knew it was probably going to be the toughest time we had with them. Just maintaining that idea of ‘we’re not done yet,’ we need to keep applying what we’re doing, not being satisfied – that is what really motivated us.”

For Russell and the rest of her senior teammates, winning both FCIAC and State titles over their rival was a fitting coda to a very special class of lacrosse players — one in which seven members are going on to play lacrosse in college.

“To be able to end our career at New Canaan on such a high note is so special,” Russell said. “We know how good we were individually, the talent is there. The main thing we wanted to represent about New Canaan as a town and as a team is that it is all about each other. It’s all about your teammates – every ground ball, every defensive stop you make you’re doing it for each other and that embodies the New Canaan mentality.”

“This group has come together since freshman year and they left it on the field,” Woods said. “The senior leaders have just been outstanding, every single one of them has meant so much to the program. They’ve carried on our culture. I know they’re going to go on to do amazing things and will accomplish so much at the next level.”

Photo Credit: Terry Dinan, Contributed to

images.alt_text: NCHS Girls Lacrosse Team Wins 2024 CIAC LL Title

New Canaan Public Schools.title: South Elementary School Named Recipient of  NASA Moon Tree Seedling

content.preview: New Canaan Public Schools
content.full_text:
South Elementary School has been selected by NASA as one of the first to receive a “Moon Tree” seedling that has flown across space aboard the Artemis I mission. Currently, South Elementary School is the first educational institution in the state of CT to receive a Moon Tree seedling and will use this opportunity to promote science, technology, engineering and math within its classrooms.

“...[This] is an exciting moment in the history of space exploration,” stated Gabriella Brown, Science Teacher at South Elementary School. “For the first time in nearly 50 years, NASA is planning to return to the Moon, and to commemorate this new era of moon exploration they sent seeds to honor Stuart Roosa’s Moon Tree experiment from the Apollo 14 mission. I thought this would be a great opportunity to foster citizenship by connecting our children with the natural world and outer space by encouraging them to become environmental stewards and citizen scientists.”

On August 24, 2023, NASA announced that their NASA Next Gen STEM Department, in partnership with the USDA Forest Service, will begin accepting applications for education and community organizations to receive a living piece of spaceflight history. This piece of history will be in the form of one of 50 seedlings grown from a tree seed aboard NASA’s Artemis I mission. Each seed traveled thousands of miles beyond the Moon and spent four weeks in space before returning back to Earth. The mission, completed in late 2022, continues the original The Moon Tree project launched in 1971 when seeds were sent into space to study the effects of prolonged weightlessness on germination.

“NASA’s Artemis moon trees are bringing the science and ingenuity of space exploration back down to Earth,” said NASA Administrator Bill Nelson in the NASA-issued press release on April 24. “Last year, these seeds flew on the Artemis I mission 40,000 miles beyond the Moon. With the help of the USDA, this new generation of Moon trees will plant the spirit of exploration across our communities and inspire the next generation of explorers.”

Over 1300 applications were submitted to NASA for review, with the first batch of trees sent to nearly 50 institutions nationwide. Recipients were chosen based on their tree care plans and proposals for implementation in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Those selected would be eligible to receive one of five species of trees grown on the 2022 Artemus I flight, including sycamores, sweetgum, Douglas firs, loblolly pines, and giant sequoias.

In mid-April, South Elementary School was notified they had been selected as one of the first organizations to receive a seedling and is the first institution in CT to be a Moon Tree Steward. The sycamore tree seedling was received on April 26 and planted the following day, on Arbor Day, on the grounds of South Elementary School.

“We have many exciting plans to incorporate the Moon Tree into our student’s education across the district,” said Brown. “The beauty is that this journey can be applied in all subjects from data collection in math, to poetry in ELA, the history of moon exploration in social studies, exploring the seasonal growth changes in science, and much more. We’re looking forward to the development of a creative space in which children of all abilities can apply classroom lessons to create something real that is valued by others.”

images.alt_text: South Elementary School Named Recipient of  NASA Moon Tree Seedling

New Canaan Public Schools.title: NCPS Celebrates Grand Opening of The Dome

content.preview: New Canaan Public Schools
content.full_text:
New Canaan Public Schools is proud to announce the grand opening of its highly anticipated immersive learning theater, The Dome, at New Canaan High School. The official ribbon-cutting ceremony took place on April 30th in a private event held with members of the Board of Education, The Dome Committee, Ad Council, PTC/PFA, and town officials, including current First Selectman Dionna Carlson and former First Selectman Kevin Moynihan.

The Dome, a cutting-edge immersive and interactive learning theater, now stands in the place of NCHS' original 1971 planetarium. The space has undergone a remarkable transformation, boasting a 30-ft, ceiling-mounted circular theater screen, dual 4K Sony projector system, LED cove lighting, and cinema-style seating. The Dome also features a state-of-the-art programming system, Digistar 7, which provides a breadth of educational experiences across various disciplines, including biology, astrology, mathematics, physics, history, art, and more. Together, these features blend visuals and sound to create a breathtaking 180-degree image, revolutionizing traditional education into a fully immersive visual, audio, and sensory experience.

"We are deeply appreciative of everyone who has been a part of this inspiring project," expressed Superintendent Dr. Bryan Luizzi. "It has been an extraordinary journey, and we are grateful for the unwavering support and dedication of those who have helped turn this vision into a reality."

The vision to transform the former planetarium into a new, modern learning center was first conceived in 2016, but plans were put on hold due to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, through a collaborative private-public fundraising initiative between the town and community members, the district revived the project in 2022. In recognition of the support and contributions from community members, the entrance to The Dome is adorned with a wall of dedication stars, each symbolizing the generous donations of New Canaan community members who played a pivotal role in turning the vision of the space into reality. Led by community member and NCPS alumni, Sara Schubert, The Dome's Committee was instrumental in driving the project forward, demonstrating the power of community in realizing ambitious educational visions.

"The Dome is a powerful example of what's possible when we come together as a community on behalf of our children," stated Superintendent Dr. Bryan Luizzi. "In a world that's driving us to look down at our small screens, isolated and alone, The Dome brings us together to share in a sense of wonder and awe. Instead of looking down and thinking small, The Dome provides a vast canvas with infinite possibilities for all of us to explore the world together in previously unimaginable ways."

The Dome is currently open for classroom use for grades K-12, with public use expected in Fall 2024.

images.alt_text: naps celebrates grand opening of the dome

New Canaan Public Schools.title: East School Welcomes Ms. Zoe Robinson as New Principal

content.preview: New Canaan Public Schools
content.full_text:
New Canaan Public Schools is pleased to announce the appointment of Ms. Zoe Robinson to the position of Principal at East Elementary School. Ms. Robinson, currently serving as Assistant Principal at South Elementary School, will take over for John Grasso, East Elementary School's interim principal, on July 1, 2024.

"We are thrilled to introduce Zoe Robinson as the new principal of East Elementary School. Zoe has been an exemplary assistant principal at South School, and is a proven leader in our district. It’s exciting to consider the great things ahead for the entire East School Community with Zoe as principal!" said NCPS Superintendent Dr. Bryan Luizzi.

Ms. Robinson's tenure at New Canaan Public Schools has been marked with many achievements. Most recently serving as assistant principal for South Elementary School, Ms. Robinson has been instrumental in implementing school-wide policies, facilitating instructional design for staff, and developing initiatives to support the district's implementation of the RULER approach for Emotional Intelligence. She has also served as New Canaan Public Schools K-8 Math Coordinator, Math Specialist at West Elementary School, and Numeracy Instructional Coach for the Mathematics Department, PreK-8, in Bridgeport, CT.

Describing the hiring process, Dr. Luizzi shared, "We had a robust applicant pool for this position, and we put together an inclusive screening, interviewing, and selection process. The committee consisted of 16 members representing various stakeholders, including the Board of Education, district administrators, teachers, parents, building administrators, and members of the NCEA [New Canaan Education Association], and I want to thank them for their excellent work. Zoe has distinguished herself in countless ways throughout her time in the district, and I’m confident she’ll be an outstanding principal and educational leader at East Elementary School.”

Ms. Robinson earned her bachelor's degree in Elementary Education from Brooklyn College, a master's degree in Curriculum, Instruction, & Assessment from Walden University, and an Intermediate Administrator Certification from Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, CT. She is currently pursuing a Doctor of Education (Ed.D.) in Educational Leadership, also from Walden University.

Ms. Robinson's official start date will be July 1, 2024.

images.alt_text: East School Welcomes Ms. Zoe Robinson as New Principal

content.full_text:

, a timeless tale that weaves together radiant melodies, captivating choreography, and a story of dreams and resilience. Whether you're a fan of classic musical theater or seeking a heartwarming, family-friendly spectacle, Cinderella promises a mesmerizing evening that will transport audiences to a realm where dreams come true and the impossible becomes possible. New Canaan Public Schools.title: South School Welcomes Ms. Siobhan McCormack as New Assistant Principal

content.preview: New Canaan Public Schools
content.full_text:
- New Canaan Public Schools is pleased to announce the appointment of Siobhan McCormack as the new Assistant Principal of South Elementary School. Ms. McCormack brings a wealth of experience and expertise to her new role, having served in various educational leadership capacities throughout her career. Ms. McCormack will replace Zoe Robinson, who has been recently appointed as the new principal of East Elementary School.

Dr. Bryan Luizzi, Superintendent of New Canaan Public Schools, expressed his enthusiasm about Ms. McCormack's appointment, stating, "We are thrilled to welcome Ms. McCormack to the New Canaan Public Schools community. Siobhan's recent experience as an assistant principal, coupled with her exemplary teaching experience, make her the ideal candidate to join our administrative team at South Elementary School."

Ms. McCormack joins New Canaan Public Schools from Ox Ridge School in Darien, CT, where she served as the Interim Assistant Principal during the 2023-2024 school year. Before this role, Ms. McCormack served as a Literacy Coach at various schools in Fairfield and Westport, and as a classroom teacher, having taught grades 4 and 5 at Riverfield School in Fairfield, CT. In response to her appointment, Ms. McCormack emphasized her commitment to collaboration, stating, "I am honored to join the dedicated team at South Elementary School and am looking forward to collaborating with the existing strong and inclusive learning environment where all students can thrive. "

Dr. Luizzi wants to thank the many members of the hiring committee who came together to interview several highly-qualified candidates for the position. “Our inclusive process included faculty, administrators, the Board of Education, and community members. Hiring new professionals to join our district is one of our most important and impactful responsibilities, and every member of the committee approached this work with the thoughtful care this responsibility deserves. Thanks to their efforts, we have identified and hired an exemplary candidate to join our administrative team, and I’m excited for Siobhan to get started!”

Ms. McCormack will officially assume her role as Assistant Principal of South Elementary School on July 1, 2024.

images.alt_text: south school welcomes ms. siobhan mccormack as new assistant principal

content.preview: Inspiring future leaders and problem-solvers through interactive programs, both inside and outside the classroom. Our single-session and multi-session workshops provide a platform for empowering youth to meet life’s challenges with confidence and competence. After-school programs for K – 12th grade. Leadership training, Craft Club, GAME ON! and community service, are just a few of the ways our youth get involved and make a difference in the lives of others.
content.full_text:
Inspiring future leaders and problem-solvers through interactive programs, both inside and outside the classroom. Our single-session and multi-session workshops provide a platform for empowering youth to meet life’s challenges with confidence and competence. After-school programs for K – 12th grade. Leadership training, Craft Club, GAME ON! and community service, are just a few of the ways our youth get involved and make a difference in the lives of others.

The GAME ON! program is a unique opportunity 2nd and 3rd third graders to learn valuable interpersonal, cooperation and collaboration skills in an non-competitive, friendly and safe environment.

Led by the CARES Education and Program Manager, along with NCL & SLOB 7th-12 grade volunteer leaders, students are presented with a multitude of interactive games and activities which facilitate communication, problem-solving, self-confidence, and resilience.

These after-school programs foster friendship and teamwork while providing a safe and fun environment for kids to be themselves.

The Middle School Leadership Program provides 7th and 8th grade students with the opportunity to work with an adult mentor and their peers on developing their leadership skills. This 6 week program is designed to help students enhance their social skills which are so important at this developmental stage.

This program is able to teach valuable skills such as team building, communication, problem solving, and public speaking through a variety of interactive games and activities. Offered after school at Saxe Middle School.

This program trains current high school students in the community to become successful driven leaders. This program leaves kids with a multitude of leadership skills designed to serve them in future endeavors even beyond their high school environments. By allowing students to step outside the classroom and get involved in a variety of community organizations, they learn they can truly make a difference in the lives of others.

Students are able to grow individually and alongside their peers in a supportive and fun environment. This knowledge-filled program leaves students capable and confident to take on the next chapter in their life. Admittance into Leadership Program is by nomination: parent, peer, self, faculty, and/or community leader. Nominations may be sent to

CARES offers private workshops for youth groups (i.e. NCL, Girl Scouts, SLOBs, etc.) on a variety of topics. Programs are offered as 1-3 session sets, with knowledge, skill, and practical application components. Topics include Peer Pressure, Exclusion, Transitions, and much more.

Please contact us to schedule a workshop for your group.

New Canaan CARES is an independent, non-profit community organization whose purpose is to advance the health and well-being of youth and families.

CARES provides responsive educational programs that support and strengthen parenting skills, positive youth development, and healthy lifestyles – free of charge.

New Canaan CARES is thrilled to partner with

featuring

Parents of preschoolers, join New Canaan CARES and Evelyn Bilias Lolis, PhD, as Dr. Evelyn shares actionable guidance for supporting positive behavior in young children using evidence-based positive psychological strategies.

content.full_text:
New Canaan CARES is an independent, non-profit community organization whose purpose is to advance the health and well-being of youth and families.

CARES provides responsive educational programs that support and strengthen parenting skills, positive youth development, and healthy lifestyles – free of charge.

Irwin House (physical)

848 Weed Street

New Canaan, CT 06840

P.O Box 178 (mailing)

New Canaan, CT 06840

New Canaan CARES is a registered 501(c)(3)

Join our community and we will keep you up to date on all our programs and events.
